newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares hurt by Ifo report at opening.
newsitem.headline: German shares hurt by Ifo report at opening.

text.p: German shares took an early dip on Wednesday after the closely-watched Ifo business climate index rose sharply in July, partly undermining hopes for an imminent cut in Germany's securities repurchase rate.
The blue-chip DAX index started down 13.10 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,547.16 points, having dipped as low as 2,539.29 points in the pre-bourse session.
Disappointing corporate earnings also hurt prices.

Construction group Philipp Holzmann AG slumped 3.7 percent to 360 marks -- the biggest decline of the day -- after it reported an 11.8 percent drop in output for the first six months of the year and said it expected a negative operating result for 1996.
Diversified utility group Viag AG dropped 4.50 marks to 562 marks amid mild disappointment at its report of a 21 percent drop in first-half pre tax profit -- the lower end of expectations.

Steel and engineering group Fried. Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp also dropped nearly three percent to 214 marks after predicting a difficult second half, which dealers said was interpreted as a profit warning.
The Krupp report also sent shares in steelmaker Thyssen AG down 1.20 marks to 262.30 marks.
Despite the strong Ifo report, dealers were still expecting the repo rate to be cut by five to 10 basis points when the Bundesbank council meets on Thursday.
"A small cut will keep the hopes for more significant cuts alive and will boost market sentiment. The big question will be, will it be enough?," said one dealer.
